conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light, creating a dark area on a surface behind the object.
The position and size of a shadow depend on the relative positions of the light source, the object, and the surface.
Four objects cast shadows labeled A, B, C, and D; shadows are directly below and slightly to the left of the objects.
When the light source moves to the front right, shadows will move towards the back left relative to their current positions.
The distance increase between the light source and objects generally causes shadows to become longer and potentially larger.
Shadow A will shift back left and elongate due to the increased distance.
Shadow B will shift back left and elongate, similar to shadow A.
Shadow C will shift further to the back left and become larger due to the increased distance.
Shadow D will move back left and elongate, similar to the other shadows.
Shadows A, B, C, and D will all shift towards the back left relative to their current positions.
The shadows will become longer and potentially larger due to the increased distance between the light source and the objects.
